title: How to deal with a sexist teacher - Quora

response.answer_text: When I was in high school, I had a teacher who hated me. You see, I was one of the first Asians to be in my town, and apparently she was a bit of a racist. But I didn’t know that at the time because I honestly never paid too much attention to school gossip. Until the day we got our mid-year tests back. I’d done rather well (or so I’d thought), but my test came back with a “B” score. I scanned through and discovered that I’d gotten an 89.5%, which should’ve been rounded up to an A. It was the stated policy for that class. But the kicker was that, as she passed back the tests, the teacher looked straight at me and said “and I thought Asians were supposed to be smart.” Well, I was outraged.  So, naturally, I go home to complain about my racist teacher. I talk to my dad, but, to my shock, he interrupts my rant with a simple question: “Why didn’t you get an A?” “Because the teacher didn’t round up and she was supposed to-” “No.” He cut me off. “That just means you were trying to do just enough to get by. Get a 100 next time, and if she rounds that down I’ll talk to the school.” And that was the end of the conversation.  Now, do I think my dad’s reaction was a bit extreme? Yeah. When I have a kid, I’ll talk to the principal. But I will also be sure to tell my kid what my dad told me. “Get a 100 next time.” You see, there are two kinds of people in life: those who are victims of circumstance, and those who are victors over circumstance. You’ve got to choose which you want to be. Circumstances come and circumstances go, and the only person you have to deal with your whole life is yourself. I haven’t spoken to any of my high school teachers in close to a decade. But every day, I’m still using the lesson that my dad taught me: If you want things to get better, hold yourself, not others, to a higher standard.  So, what’s my advice? If you want, go ahead and talk to your principal about your sexist teacher. Talk to your parents. Start a petition. Make the world a better place. Or, if you want, you can study extra hard, put your head down, and resolve never to speak to him/her again after you graduate. But never start believing that what happens to you is just the result of bad circumstance. If you act like a victim, the world will walk all over you. But if you set your sights on who you want to be, and stop giving a **** about what everyone else has to say about it, you’ll wake up one day and realize that all the people who thought you weren’t going to make it are decades behind and miles below where you are now.

Sexism isn’t just a quirk that some teachers have that you have to deal with. It’s not just one of life’s little unfairnesses that you have to learn to live with. It’s a civil rights violation and a moral injustice. If you are sure that there is sexism operating, start documenting immediately—you can’t do anything with just your feeling of persecution. Once you have documented examples and talked to classmates who will also report that they heard and saw similar things, you can go to the administration. Chances are that the administration will simply speak to the teacher, but if it’s not the first complaint, there might be more serious repercussions. Also, it’s your complaint, but if you take a parent with you to lay it out, it might help emphasize the seriousness of your issue. Good luck. Life is hard enough without having to deal with someone else’s arbitrary prejudice.

The best way to deal with a teacher who underestimate you is by: A/ Proving them wrong by success B/ Communicate it to them after graduation When a teacher attempts to make you think or feel that you are not good enough based on your sex, try to prove them wrong by doing your best and working harder to achieve the goals they think you can’t possibly reach. After you reach your goal and meet them in person, try to communicate the problem with respect and well chose words. Tell them that you knew what they thought of you when you were their student and that you think it was ignorant and inhumane. Make them aware of your success then, and make them sure of your future success. Such a person needs to be aware of their mistake, feel ashamed of it, and probably drive them to correct it and avoid it in the future. Other than that, I don’t always think talking to the principle is the greatest idea since you don’t always get what you want and sometimes things can get worse. Instead, try to communicate your problem with the people you trust most to keep it secret and to help you get through the bad times this teacher might put you through. Feel good about yourself and don’t let others bring you down.

‘You’ll never do as well as the girls, they’re much harder working by nature and they’re better at psychology’.  All I had done was discuss the up coming test with my teacher, told her what she expected from me. She told me I would do well but the girls would beat all the boys. There are 3 boys in our class and about 10 girls. I wouldn’t stand by and take this. I studied like a machine, I worked harder than I had before. I would prove her wrong, guys are just as hard working. It’s not something that disappears with the Y chromosome. I scored 96%, beaten by 1 stupid mark from the top student. (Yes, she was a girl) I gave teacher a cheeky smile as she showed me my rank out of all the year 12’s. ‘Miss, I’m a guy, isn’t it funny that nearly all the girls scored less than me?’ That silenced her. Work hard, ignore your teachers comments and silence them through your actions. (Edit: Although the other boys in the class scored the bottom marks, I still thank my teacher for her sexism. I wouldn’t have studied so hard if she hadn’t challenged my work ethic). Peace ✌️

You can argue with her or you can lay down and try to get a good grade. I think if it were me, I’d start with a letter to the editor of the school paper. I’d say that in a recent lecture in my psych class the teacher stated “XXX” and then went on to say ”XXX.” Don’t name her. Assume that she will know who she is. After that, say that you were offended, that those statements aren’t any kind of a reflection of who you are and that you’re definitely a man. Say that most of the statements she makes concerning men are really only true of a handful of immature boys posing as men and not representative of the gender. Go from there.

Learn from them. Your view is only an opinion and you might be wrong. On the other hand, we are all human with our own prejudices. Rather than being judgmental in return, try to understand why your teacher said something that made you think that. You might come to understand that person better, or you might not. In the end, you only have to deal with that person for a limited time anyhow. There will be LOTS OF PEOPLE WITH OPINIONS. YOU ARE ONE OF THEM. So chill, and get on with your work.
